items.synopsis: Israel says it is at war as its soldiers battle Hamas fighters in the streets of southern Israel and launch air strikes on Gaza. Follow live.

title.children: 'A machine gun started going off': Australian describes fleeing music festival near Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has expressed his "horror and outrage" at the loss of life from "abhorrent" atatcks in Israel. "To see young people chased into the desert and gunned down, to see women and children dragged into the back of vehicles [and] taken hostage is just completely and utterly abhorrent," he said at a press conference in Tasmania. Mr Dutton agreed the acts should be condemned and said Australia should provide "very strong words of encouragement" to Israel and its government which should be "pursuing" the people behind the attacks with "every asset available to them". "When people talk about Israel having to show restraint, it is completely and utterly the wrong time for that sort of language," he said. Watch the press conference below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dutton says taking women, children as hostages is 'utterly abhorrent'

children.content: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has expressed his "horror and outrage" at the loss of life from "abhorrent" atatcks in Israel.

"To see young people chased into the desert and gunned down, to see women and children dragged into the back of vehicles [and] taken hostage is just completely and utterly abhorrent," he said at a press conference in Tasmania.

Mr Dutton agreed the acts should be condemned and said Australia should provide "very strong words of encouragement" to Israel and its government which should be "pursuing" the people behind the attacks with "every asset available to them".
"When people talk about Israel having to show restraint, it is completely and utterly the wrong time for that sort of language," he said.
Watch the press conference below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We have an update on the UN Security Council's emergency meeting. It has taken no immediate action on a demand from the United States that all 15 members strongly condemn "these heinous terrorist attacks committed by Hamas". US deputy ambassador Robert Wood said after the meeting that "a good number of countries", but not all, denounced the unprecedented incursion by Hamas into Israel on Saturday morning. Russia's UN ambassador, Vassily Nebenzia, told The Associated Press that the US was trying to say at the meeting that Russia isn't condemning the attacks, but "that’s untrue". "It was in my comments," Mr Nebenzia said. "We condemn all the attacks on civilians." He said Russia's message was: "It's important to stop the fighting immediately, to go to a cease-fire, and to meaningful negotiations which were stalled for decades." China’s UN ambassador, Zhang Jun, expressed a similar position as he headed into the meeting. But Mr Wood said the international community must strongly condemn "this unprovoked invasion and the terrorist attacks" until Hamas ends its "violent terrorist activity against the Israeli people". AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: UN takes no immediate action after emergency meeting

children.content: We have an update on the
UN Security Council's
emergency meeting.
It has taken
no immediate action
on a demand from the United States that all 15 members strongly condemn "these heinous terrorist attacks committed by Hamas".
US deputy ambassador Robert Wood said after the meeting that "a good number of countries", but not all, denounced the unprecedented incursion by Hamas into Israel on Saturday morning.
Russia's UN ambassador, Vassily Nebenzia, told The Associated Press that the US was trying to say at the meeting that Russia isn't condemning the attacks, but "that’s untrue".
"It was in my comments," Mr Nebenzia said. "We condemn all the attacks on civilians."
Russia’s UN ambassador Vassily Nebenzia.
(AP Photo: John Minchillo)
He said Russia's message was: "It's important to stop the fighting immediately, to go to a cease-fire, and to meaningful negotiations which were stalled for decades."
China’s UN ambassador, Zhang Jun, expressed a similar position as he headed into the meeting.
But Mr Wood said the international community must strongly condemn "this unprovoked invasion and the terrorist attacks" until Hamas ends its "violent terrorist activity against the Israeli people".
AP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We heard earlier that the US doesn't have any evidence Iran was involved in the Hamas attack, but that is their concern. Reuters has just dropped an update from Tehran. Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi said during a cabinet meeting the attack on Israel was "a manifestation of resistance and standing against the fake Zionist regime". "The Palestinian people, the Palestinian soldiers, all Palestinian groups, and the Islamic Ummah really should be congratulated for this victory." President Raisi has referred to "Palestinian people", but it's important to note the difference between the soldiers of Hamas and the civilian population. The attack on Israel was a Hamas operation.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Iran weighs in

children.content: We heard earlier that the US doesn't have any evidence Iran was involved in the Hamas attack, but that is their concern.
Reuters has just dropped an update from Tehran.
Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi said during a cabinet meeting the attack on Israel was "a manifestation of resistance and standing against the fake Zionist regime".
"The Palestinian people, the Palestinian soldiers, all Palestinian groups, and the Islamic Ummah really should be congratulated for this victory."
President Raisi has referred to "Palestinian people", but it's important to note the difference between the soldiers of Hamas and the civilian population. The attack on Israel was a Hamas operation.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Casey Briggs The ABC's poll of the polls now puts Yes at an average of 41.2 per cent, well behind No at 58.8 per cent. For Yes, that's well below the level of support that was recorded in the republic referendum in 1999, which failed with just over 45 per cent of the national vote. "I'm old enough to remember that at the time, it didn't feel about a week out that the case for change was in a particularly good place," Professor Simon Jackman from the University of Sydney says. "It sort of feels that way with respect to this referendum too." The model, developed by Jackman, is an effort to understand the polling that has been published, and is not a prediction of the outcome of the vote. Find out more about what polls are telling us about the Voice to Parliament referendum.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What are the polls saying less than a week from the referendum?

featuredLink.title: How is the Voice polling with less than a week to October 14?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More than 2.2 million Aussies have already cast their vote, according to Australian Electoral Commission data. One of those Australians is Prime Minister Anthony Albanese who cast his vote with his son, Nathan, at an inner west Sydney early voting place over the weekend. "I cast my vote today for Yes and I did so proudly in the knowledge that this is the request of Indigenous Australians," Mr Albanese said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Millions of Australians have already voted

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Oil prices have surged by more than 5% today as Israel officially declared war over the Hamas attack over the weekend. Not only has it triggered political uncertainty in the Middle East, it's also got investors on edge about what might happen with oil and the associated oil price. The price of brent crude is currently up by 5.1%, to around $US88.95 a barrel — that's a jump of over $US4.30 since this morning. Commonwealth Bank analysts this morning wrote that last week, brent was down 11.3% last week to $US84.58 — the largest weekly drop since March, and erased the gains from extended production cuts from Saudi Arabia and Russia. "Developments in Israel and Gaza complicate the geopolitical picture for risk markets," CBA analysts said. "While there can be expected to be few direct supply interruptions for oil without a broadening of the conflict, stricter enforcement of Iranian sanctions and waning hopes of more Saudi supply through 2024 alongside a normalisation of Saudi-Israeli relations have been cited by some analysts as potential immediate impacts." Although the latest events in the Middle East don't necessarily mean supply is under threat, the increasing geopolitical risk should support higher prices and greater volatility, ANZ analysts noted.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Oil prices jump by 5pc as violence in the Middle East triggers uncertainty

children.content: Oil prices have surged by more than 5% today
as Israel officially declared war over the Hamas attack over the weekend.
Not only has it triggered political uncertainty in the Middle East, it's also got investors on edge about what might happen with oil and the associated oil price.
The price of brent crude is currently
up by 5.1%
, to around
$US88.95 a barrel
— that's a
jump of over $US4.30
since this morning.
Commonwealth Bank analysts this morning wrote that last week,
brent was down 11.3% last week to $US84.58
— the largest weekly drop since March, and erased the gains from extended production cuts from Saudi Arabia and Russia.
"Developments in Israel and Gaza complicate the geopolitical picture for risk markets," CBA analysts said.

"While there can be expected to be few direct supply interruptions for oil without a broadening of the conflict, stricter enforcement of Iranian sanctions and waning hopes of more Saudi supply through 2024 alongside a normalisation of Saudi-Israeli relations have been cited by some analysts as potential immediate impacts."
Although the latest events in the Middle East don't necessarily mean supply is under threat, the increasing geopolitical risk should support higher prices and greater volatility, ANZ analysts noted.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you've been paying attention to the news in recent months (and why wouldn't you be, you're on a business and markets blog after all) you'll be familiar with the story of climate protesters targeting the home of Woodside CEO Meg O'Neill. The climate protesters were widely condemned for targeting Ms O'Neill's private home in August, which was was filmed by Four Corners for an upcoming story, and has been the subject of dozens of headlines since the incident happened. Now, the full story from the Four Corners team has been published — and you can read the inside story of what happened when climate protesters targeted the Woodside boss from reporte rs Hagar Cohen, Mayeta Clark and Dylan Welch below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX has opened higher at the beginning of trade on Monday morning, up 0.4% to 6,982 points as of 10:35am AEDT. (If you want more up-to-date figures, jump to the top of the blog and expand the pinned post for live market updates for the major ASX indices.) Energy stocks are mostly responsible for the higher opening, with the sector up 2.1%. The basic materials sector is also up 1.3%, while academic and educational services picked up 0.9%. Utilities (+0.5%), consumer cyclicals (+0.4%) and real estate (+0.2%) round out the early gains for the sectors. Consumer non-cyclicals have had the biggest drop so far (-0.6%), followed by industrials (-0.1%). The technology, healthcare and financials sectors are all flat. The best performers so far: De Grey Mining +8.5% Bellevue Gold +6.9% Evolution Mining +5.7% Capricorn Metals +5.5% Northern Star Resources +5.4% And the worst performers so far: Weebit Nano -10.9% Magellan Financial -2.7% Qantas -1.7% Paladin Energy -1.5% Life360 -1.3%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Boost in energy stocks sends ASX higher at beginning of trade

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Throughout these trade blogs I'm going to cast an eye over to the draft class of 2023 and a few of the names you'll need to know in the weeks, months and years ahead. And where else to start but Harley Reid? You've probably heard of him already, and are wondering if they incredible hype around this teenager could possibly be justified. I'm here to tell you it is. I saw him play for the first time last year and was completely blown away. Nothing I've seen this season has changed that, and recent performances for Essendon's VFL team and in the Coates League finals for Bendigo have me convinced he's as any draft prospect I've seen for a long time. Reid is the perfect modern-day player, the Martin/Petracca/De Goey prototype who can blitz through stoppages as a midfielder or dominate one-on-one as a forward. His footy smarts are underrated and his skill by hand and foot is fantastic. There are slight concerns over his fitness levels, but from what I saw over the course of the season that improved through the year. No doubt it will improve further on an AFL list. He is an electric footballer, an infectious personality and a player that will get fans through the gates. The hype is real, Harley Reid is very special.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Draft Spotlight — Harley Reid

children.content: (Getty Images)
Throughout these trade blogs I'm going to cast an eye over to the draft class of 2023 and a few of the names you'll need to know in the weeks, months and years ahead.
And where else to start but Harley Reid?
You've probably heard of him already, and are wondering if they incredible hype around this teenager could possibly be justified. I'm here to tell you it is.

I saw him play for the first time last year and was completely blown away. Nothing I've seen this season has changed that, and recent performances for Essendon's VFL team and in the Coates League finals for Bendigo have me convinced he's as any draft prospect I've seen for a long time.

Reid is the perfect modern-day player, the Martin/Petracca/De Goey prototype who can blitz through stoppages as a midfielder or dominate one-on-one as a forward. His footy smarts are underrated and his skill by hand and foot is fantastic.
There are slight concerns over his fitness levels, but from what I saw over the course of the season that improved through the year. No doubt it will improve further on an AFL list.
He is an electric footballer, an infectious personality and a player that will get fans through the gates. The hype is real, Harley Reid is very special.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Crows have opted not to match the contract offered to Tom Doedee by Brisbane. They have received end of first round compensation (currently pick 19) from the AFL. That will get bumped back as other compo picks come in, and even further on draft night. But still, that's an incredible result for the Crows. Everyone shakes hands and goes home happy with that one.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Adelaide to receive first round pick for Tom Doedee

The Crows have opted not to match the contract offered to Tom Doedee by Brisbane.
They have received end of first round compensation (currently pick 19) from the AFL. That will get bumped back as other compo picks come in, and even further on draft night.
But still, that's an incredible result for the Crows. Everyone shakes hands and goes home happy with that one.
